document.masterDocTitle: Fifteen new species of Chilicola (Oroediscelis) (Hymenoptera: Colletidae: Xeromelissinae) with illustrated keys to the males and females of the subgenus

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Fifteen new species of Chilicola (Oroediscelis) (Hymenoptera: Colletidae: Xeromelissinae) with illustrated keys to the males and females of the subgenus

heading.emphasis:
Key to the Females of
Chilicola
(O roediscelis ) (Females of
C. ashei
,
C. fritzi
,
C. boharti
and
C. pustulata
unknown)

keyStep.keyLead:
3(2) Mesoscutum with dense, long pubescence, longest hairs ~2.5 MOD ( Fig. 135 ).................
C. espeleticola Michener Mesoscutum
with sparse, short pubescence, longest hairs <1 MOD ( Fig. 136 )...................................... 4

caption.paragraph:
FIGURES 129–130. Head, frontal view, to show relative length: width. 129. L~1.5XW (
C. calchaqui
holotype); 130. L<1.35W (
C. carPenteri
paratype).

FIGURES 131–132. Heads, side view to show relative length:width of malar space. 131. L clearly> W (
C. calchaqui
holotype); 132. L<W (
C. carPenteri
paratype).

FIGURES 133–134. Heads, side view to show relative length:width of malar space. 133. L~=W (
C. roigi
paratype); 134. L<0.75W (
C. boharti
paratype).

FIGURES 135–136. Head and mesosoma , side view, to show relative length of pubescence. 135. long (
C. esPeleticola
); 136. short (
C. carPenteri
paratype).

keyStep.keyLead:
4(3) Frontal and upper paraocular areas deeply and coarsely punctate ( Fig. 137 ); metapostnotum with sparse striae not reaching posterior edge ( Fig. 139 ).............................................................
C. bigibbosa Michener Frontal
and upper paraocular areas shallowly punctate ( Fig. 138 ); metapostnotum with dense striae throughout, most reaching posterior edge ( Fig. 140 )....................................................
C. roigi Packer and Dumesh
n. sp.

caption.paragraph:
FIGURES 137–138. Heads anterodorsal view, to show punctures of frontal and upper paraocular areas: 137. deep and distinct (
C. bigibbosa
); 138. shallow, less distinct (
C. roigi
paratype).

FIGURES 139–140. Metapostnotum, dorsal view, to show relative lengths of striae: 139. not attaining posterior margin of dorsal surface of metapostnotum (
C. bigibbosa
); 140. most striae attaining posterior margin (
C. roigi
paratype).

keyStep.keyLead:
5(2) Mesoscutum with dense, long pubescence, longest hairs ~2.5 MOD ( Fig. 141 )..................
C. deborahae Gonzalez Mesoscutum
with sparse, scattered pubescence, longest hairs ~1 MOD ( Fig. 142 ).................................. 6

6(5) Lower paraocular area with distinct yellow-orange mark laterad of anterior tentoral pit ( Fig. 143 ).............................................................................................
C. jaguense Packer and Dumesh
n. sp. Lower paraocular area without distinct yellow mark (rarely with faint orange marking) ( Fig. 144 )..................... 7

caption.paragraph:
FIGURES 143–144. Face, anterior view to show: 143. presence (
C. jaguense
holotype) and 144. absence of yellow maculation (
C. huarPe
holotype).

keyStep.keyLead:
8(7) Head 1.2X as long as wide; larger bees, head width 1.7 mm ( Fig. 147 )..............
C. goloboffi Packer and Dumesh
n. sp. Head at least 1.25X as long as wide; smaller bees, head width < 1.5 mm ( Fig. 148 )................................. 9

caption.paragraph:
FIGURES 145–146. Head, side view to show relative length: width of malar space. 145. L~0.75W (
C. carPenteri
paratype); 146. L<2/3W (
C. brzoskai
).

FIGURES 147–148. Head, frontal view, to show relative length to width. 147. L~1.2XW (
C. goloboffi
paratype); 148. L>1.25W (
C. carPenteri
paratype).

keyStep.keyLead:
9(8) Metapostnotal striae uniform, fine but dense ( Fig. 149 ); apical impressed area of T1–T2 punctate medially ( Fig. 151 ).............................................................................
C. capillitas Packer and Dumesh
n. sp. Metapostnotal striae not uniform, somewhat coarse and sparse ( Fig. 150 ); apical impressed area of T1–T2 impunctate medially ( Fig. 152 )............................................................
C. carpenteri Packer and Dumesh
n. sp.

caption.paragraph:
FIGURES 149–150. Metapostnotum, dorsal view, to show striae. 149. long, moderately dense and fine (
C. caPillitas
paratype); 150. short, relatively sparse and coarse (
C. carPenteri
paratype).

FIGURES 151–152. T1 – T2 dorsal view to show: 151. presence (
C. caPillitas
paratype) and 152. absence of punctation on apical impressed area medially (
C. carPenteri
paratype).

FIGURES 153–154. Head side view to show relative length:width of malar space. 153. L~2/3W (
C. cuyense
holotype); 154. L~1/2W (
C. rozeni
paratype).

keyStep.keyLead:
11(10) Metasomal terga triply punctate, with largest punctures shallow and crater-like, most evident laterally on T2–T4 among smaller punctures that are of two distinct sizes; T1 sparsely punctate ( Fig. 155 )...........
C. luna Dumesh & Packer
n. sp. Metasomal terga doubly punctate, or with punctures of only one size; T1 densely punctate ( Fig. 156 )................. 12

caption.paragraph:
FIGURES 155–156. T1 – T4 to show punctation: 155. T2 with large punctures as well as moderate and small ones, T1 with sparse punctation (
C. luna
holotype); 156. T2 lacking large punctures but with moderate and small punctures both present, T1 with dense punctation (
C. huarPe
holotype).

keyStep.keyLead:
12(11) Metapostnotal striae short, not reaching posterior margin ( Fig. 157 ); T1 surface shiny to weakly imbricate, punctures distinct ( Fig. 159 )...............................................................
C. huarpe Packer and Dumesh
n. sp. Metapostnotal striae long, at least some reaching posterior margin ( Fig. 158 ); T1 strongly imbricate, dull, punctures sometimes indistinct among surface sculpture ( Fig. 160 )..................................
C. cuyense Dumesh and Packer
n. sp.

caption.paragraph:
FIGURES 157–158. Metapostnotum, dorsal view, to show relative lengths of striae. 157. not attaining posterior margin (
C. huarPe
holotype); 158. at least some striate attaining posterior margin (
C. cuyense
holotype).

FIGURES 159–160. T1 to show relative strength of microsculpture and punctures. 159. microsculpture weak, surface shiny, punctures distinct (
C. huarPe
holotype); 160. microsculpture strong, surface dull, punctures often indistinct (
C. cuyense
holotype).

keyStep.keyLead:
13(10) Body length about 5 mm ; F1 as long as F2 on mesal surface ( Fig. 161 ); frontal area shiny with fine punctures ( Fig. 163 ).........................................................................................
C. simplex Michener Body
length greater than 6 mm ; F1 longer than F2 on mesal surface ( Fig. 162 ); frontal area dull, coarsely punctate or weakly rugose ( Fig. 164 ).................................................................................... 14

14(13) Mesoscutellum with punctures clearly of two different sizes, small punctures much more abundant than larger ones ( Fig. 16 5 )................................................................................
C. benoistiana Michener Mesoscutellum
with punctures all quite large, rarely with a very few minute ones ( Fig. 166 )........................ 15

caption.paragraph:
FIGURES 167–168. Mesoscutum, dorsal view, to show punctation between notalices. 167. uniform in size, similar to those of adjacent region of mesoscutum (
C. abrebotellas
paratype); 168. with numerous small punctures and few larger ones, the latter more similar in size to those of adjacent region of mesoscutum (
C. transversaria
).

keyStep.keyLead:
16(15) Body longer (~ 7 mm ); mesepisternum with short white hairs ( Fig. 169 ).........
C. abrebotellas Packer and Dumesh
n. sp. Body shorter (< 6 mm ); mesepisternum with long white hairs ( Fig. 170 )..............
C. rozeni Packer and Dumesh
n. sp.
